node.text:
Visit @ecologyst_ to learn more // Film by @gogoandthebandit @mommehalbe and @cammacarthur. Featuring @tjwatt @ola_randellini @drsuzannesimard. 

Slicing down a living giant that is hundreds, perhaps thousands of years old, and turning it into decking or roofing is not worth the price of an ancient ecosystem. Click the link in my bio to sign the petition to protect Fairy Creek and take a stand for British Columbia’s last remaining Old Growth Forests. Then tag a friend below to do the same. Old-growth forests take centuries to become the finely tuned systems we see today. They support vast networks of biodiversity in ways scientists are only just starting to understand. These are forests that we will never be able to replicate. Once it’s cut, it’s gone. So speak out, share this far and wide, and write our local policymakers to demand a moratorium on logging Canada’s ancient primary forests. Together we can protect the last of our forests’ true Titans. 
@fairycreekblockade @ancientforestalliance 

#oldgrowth #indigenousrights #rainforest #climatechange #ancientforest #fairycreekblockade #worthmorestanding #ancientforest #conservation #saveoldgrowth #nature #bcforests #westcoast #thereisnoplanetb #welovetheearth

node.text: 🔈 Please turn your volume up to meet Shaba, the first matriarch of the Reteti Elephant Sanctuary @r.e.s.c.u.e, in this deeply moving film by my good friend @AmiVitale. Shaba’s shining spirit and resilience in the wake of tragedy is the medicine this world needs now more than ever. Click the link in my bio or visit shabafilm.org to watch her story on-demand until August 31st. All proceeds from the tickets go directly to supporting Shaba’s community of rescued elephants and the dedicated keepers who are working to rehabilitate them back to the wild. The sanctuary is Indigenous-owned and run by the Samburu community- the first initiative of its kind. Please give them a follow and share this video far and wide.  @sararafoundation @conservationorg @kenyawildlifeservice @nrt_kenya @tusk_org @sandiegozoo @thephotosociety @passionplanet #shabafilm #shaba #retetielephants  #DontLetThemDisappear #elephants #saveelephants #stoppoaching #kenya #natureisspeaking #conservation

node.text:
There is a reason why we taste salt in our tears when we cry. It’s a reminder that when the ocean dies, so do we. The sea gives us food, medicine and keeps our climate in balance. It is the birthplace of life itself, and if we are not careful with its gifts, we will lose everything. Video by @sheltondupreez 

My life began far from the shore in Mexico. But even as a little girl, I could hear that rising call from the tides begging to be answered. I would pour over books on the sea and marvel at the strange creatures looking back at me from the pages. Some of us fear what lies beneath the surface, forgetting that we too once called the ocean home- long before our ancestors crawled on land. I, however, have always been enthralled by it. The second I had the chance to explore its briny depths, I jumped straight in and never looked back. Images shot on my @SonyXperia 1III.  @SonyXperiaUS #SonyXperia #Xperia1III #TakenWithXperia.

node.text:
One thing that blew my mind when I first moved to Vancouver Island was the fact that old-growth rainforest used to cover the entire landmass and because of industrial logging, today, 90% is gone.  Gone!  Old trees play a critical role in boosting the immunity of a forest. When we cut them down, we lose the blueprint of an entire ecosystem’s resilience. Across Canada, we’ve learned the hard way a forest is not just a grove of trees. We cannot level what took hundreds, sometimes thousands, of years for nature to perfect and expect it all to come back. Click the link in my bio to urge our government officials to protect Fairy Creek and the last of British Columbia’s old growth forests, before it is too late. @fairycreekblockade 

Video by @ReelWater

node.text:
Of all the places I have visited in the ocean, Timor-Leste’s reefs and tropical waters were some of the most spectacular wonders I have ever seen. Please turn your volume up for this behind-the-scenes-look into Timor-Leste’s incredible marine biodiversity and experience for yourself the most surprising animal encounter that changed all of our lives 🐋 The communities of Timor-Leste have depended on and cared for their seas for generations. Through the traditional use of marine resource management, this ocean nation is establishing itself as a world leader in marine conservation, responsible ecotourism, and locally-managed fishing. All you have to do to see the effects of these culturally-rooted practices is peek beneath the surface and you’ll find reefs overflowing with colorful schools of fish, coral, anemones, and even blue whales- the largest animal in the history of Earth. Join us @sealegacy and @onlyone by becoming part of #TheTide and help support places like Timor-Leste through our mission to create community-based action for our ocean. 

On expedition for @sealegacy in Timor-Leste with @PaulNicklen, @andy_mann, and @sonyalpha. #ShotOnSony #SonyAlpha #BeAlpha

node.text:
The story of our ocean is one of triumph, heartbreak, and life in its most spectacular forms- but it is far from complete. There are gaps in the narrative and there has never been a more crucial time to come together as storytellers to shine a light on the challenges our planet faces. Across the world, marginalized communities struggle to survive on the edge of a dwindling sea. Entire species are quietly disappearing along with vast stretches of coral reefs and seagrass beds. This is where I am drawn to as a photographer and marine conservationist; the silences, the empty spaces. It’s why @PaulNicklen and I set sail on the @SeaLegacy 1 and work every day to shine a light on our ocean’s greatest threats and bring the solutions that can change the world to life. Thank you @SonyAlpha for making our work possible. And thank you to my dearest friend and diving partner @Andy_Mann for directing this masterpiece. #SonyAlpha 

Director / Editor: @Andy_Mann
EP: @Mparns @CurtisMorgan
DP: @SamKretch
AC: @Kyle.Roepke

node.text:
For decades, the Galápagos marine reserve protected a vital ecosystem so diverse, it forever changed our very understanding of life on Earth. But the iconic park is no longer enough. Since the day it was established, our world population has more than doubled and our seas are depleting faster than at any point in human history. As beautiful and rich as the preserve is, it cannot help restore our ocean and support local economies if its borders are flanked and breached by an army of fishing fleets from faraway shores. Join us in calling on President Lenín Moreno @leninmorenog and President of the National Assembly @cesarlitardo to expand the world heritage site and meet the new challenges of a rapidly changing climate head on. We are on the brink of a new decade in conservation, one that will ultimately define the fate of all marine life. Sign and share the petition linked in my bio and urge Ecuador’s government to lead us all into a sustainable future. @mas_galapagos2020 @sealegacy @onlyone 
Thanks to @luksth and @dvfernandez for lending your voices
.
.
@mission_blue @migramarnet

node.text: If there’s one thing I’ve learned as a conservationist and artist, it’s to never underestimate the power of storytelling. As one of the oldest forms of communication for human beings, stories can be a powerful means to rally each other to action. This Thursday, join us in celebrating the ocean heroes who are changing hearts and sparking movements through their photography and visual storytelling at the virtual Ocean Photography Awards Show. The show will be streaming on the new Ocean Photography Awards YouTube channel starting at 2pm ET (11am PT). Click the link in my bio to access the awards. I want to thank our participants for submitting some of the most evoking work I’ve seen in photography. Your images and powerful stories have given me such hope for our planet. This will be the decade that defines the future of marine conservation and it all starts with you and your passion for our ocean. I can’t wait for this Thursday! #oceanstory #oceanphotography

node.text: When my good friend Kris founded @Paka (link in bio), he sought to empower local Indigenous communities by going directly to the Quechua people of the Andes and working closely with them to produce clothing through the traditional art of weaving alpaca fur; a practice that has sustained Quechua communities for thousands of years. He met with women weavers across the region to design a business model that would give them financial security, opportunity, and autonomy while honoring their culture. Kris and the @Paka family kept the traditional Quechua values of respecting the natural world at their core to produce sustainable pieces meant to last for years to come. When you purchase from Paka, you’re investing in local communities, supporting Indigenous women, and reducing the amount of microplastics that end up in the ocean. Half the proceeds from any purchase you make through the special link in my bio also supports @SeaLegacy and our work in ocean conservation. Click the link in my bio to learn more.

node.text: The second I plunged beneath the surface, the icy waters shocked me to the core and knocked the air from my lungs. For a moment all I could do was float in the dark and feel my teeth chatter. Then a soft whistle broke the silent gloom and I found myself immersed in a cheery pod of orcas, the cold completely forgotten. The Arctic waters of Lofoten are flourishing with the healthiest population of orcas in the world, but seismic oil and gas exploration threaten to unravel the balance of Norway’s iconic fjords. I invite you all to join us on November 10th at 7pm EST for the screening of @OnlyOne’s new short documentary film “Echoes in the Arctic” followed by a Q&A with @PaulNicklen, @AndyMaser, @TahriasHeather and I. RVSP through the link in my bio.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Cristina Mittermeier on July 27, 2021. May be an image of 1 person and waterfall.

node.text: Before I became a photographer, my path as a young conservationist and marine biologist led me to the heart of some of the most extraordinary ecosystems in the world. Those early days were full of so much life and beauty. However, over time I began to watch the wild places I had grown to love so much die away: healthy jungle was slashed to make way for rows of palms, mangroves were ripped out of the shallows for hotels, and dams were built that flooded entire communities out of their homes and ancestral lands. That was when I first felt the urge to pick up a camera. I knew it was long past time we were all reminded of the ancient connection we share with our ocean and living planet — that familial power nature holds over all of us. I create images to showcase the beauty of a thriving ecosystem and inspire action for our planet.

node.text:
Shot on @SonyXperia #Xperia1III // Life is slowly coming back to normal in the Abacos. Amidst the destruction left behind by hurricane Dorian almost 2 years ago, some sense of normalcy is starting to emerge. The ubiquitous “conch salad” beach stand that defines most islands in the archipelago has come back to life on Marsh Harbour. Bad news for the conch, but a very welcome sight for the locals.
@Sonyxperia @SonyXperiaUS #Xperia1III #SonyXperia #TravelByXperia #Mobilephotography #TakenWithXperia

node.text:
Visit @ecologyst_ to learn more // Film by @gogoandthebandit @mommehalbe and @cammacarthur. Featuring @tjwatt @ola_randellini @drsuzannesimard. 

Slicing down a living giant that is hundreds, perhaps thousands of years old, and turning it into decking or roofing is not worth the price of an ancient ecosystem. Click the link in my bio to sign the petition to protect Fairy Creek and take a stand for British Columbia’s last remaining Old Growth Forests. Then tag a friend below to do the same. Old-growth forests take centuries to become the finely tuned systems we see today. They support vast networks of biodiversity in ways scientists are only just starting to understand. These are forests that we will never be able to replicate. Once it’s cut, it’s gone. So speak out, share this far and wide, and write our local policymakers to demand a moratorium on logging Canada’s ancient primary forests. Together we can protect the last of our forests’ true Titans. 
@fairycreekblockade @ancientforestalliance 

#oldgrowth #indigenousrights #rainforest #climatechange #ancientforest #fairycreekblockade #worthmorestanding #ancientforest #conservation #saveoldgrowth #nature #bcforests #westcoast #thereisnoplanetb #welovetheearth

node.text: "Antarctic Cascade"; available for purchase as a fine art print through the link in my bio / The fluke of a humpback whale lifts above the sea in the warm glow of dusk off the coast of the Antarctic peninsula. I have chased these giants across the planet with my camera. Each year, they travel tens of thousands of miles between their feeding and breeding grounds, following some innate compass across the ocean the way their ancestors have for generations. Each sighting is as exhilarating as the last and, as this titan slipped back beneath the surface in a spectacular dive, I stood spellbound in the fading light pondering the amazing return from the brink of extinction these beautiful animals have made. To learn more about this image and view my fine art portfolio, click the link in my bio.

node.text: 🔈 Please turn your volume up to meet Shaba, the first matriarch of the Reteti Elephant Sanctuary @r.e.s.c.u.e, in this deeply moving film by my good friend @AmiVitale. Shaba’s shining spirit and resilience in the wake of tragedy is the medicine this world needs now more than ever. Click the link in my bio or visit shabafilm.org to watch her story on-demand until August 31st. All proceeds from the tickets go directly to supporting Shaba’s community of rescued elephants and the dedicated keepers who are working to rehabilitate them back to the wild. The sanctuary is Indigenous-owned and run by the Samburu community- the first initiative of its kind. Please give them a follow and share this video far and wide.  @sararafoundation @conservationorg @kenyawildlifeservice @nrt_kenya @tusk_org @sandiegozoo @thephotosociety @passionplanet #shabafilm #shaba #retetielephants  #DontLetThemDisappear #elephants #saveelephants #stoppoaching #kenya #natureisspeaking #conservation

node.text:
There is a reason why we taste salt in our tears when we cry. It’s a reminder that when the ocean dies, so do we. The sea gives us food, medicine and keeps our climate in balance. It is the birthplace of life itself, and if we are not careful with its gifts, we will lose everything. Video by @sheltondupreez 

My life began far from the shore in Mexico. But even as a little girl, I could hear that rising call from the tides begging to be answered. I would pour over books on the sea and marvel at the strange creatures looking back at me from the pages. Some of us fear what lies beneath the surface, forgetting that we too once called the ocean home- long before our ancestors crawled on land. I, however, have always been enthralled by it. The second I had the chance to explore its briny depths, I jumped straight in and never looked back. Images shot on my @SonyXperia 1III.  @SonyXperiaUS #SonyXperia #Xperia1III #TakenWithXperia.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Cristina Mittermeier on July 21, 2021. May be an image of 1 person, big cat and nature.

node.text:
Some days I have to pinch myself to believe that I get to spend my life with a partner who shares my passion for wildlife, art, and nature. To celebrate @PaulNicklen's birthday today, I want to invite you all to Join The Tide through the link in my bio and help us save the ocean! If you join us before 11:59 pm Eastern Time on July 25th, you'll be entered to win* Paul's Super Sea Wolf 53 Zodiac watch.

Recently, I asked @PaulNicklen what he most wanted for his birthday.  Without hesitation, he replied: “I wish I could just save the ocean.” I know the feeling, as I am keenly aware that saving the ocean offers us the biggest bang for our buck when it comes to building resilience and putting a dent in the massive dual threats of climate change and biodiversity loss. We don’t have a magic wand, but we know that through the power of our will and voices demanding action and investing in solutions, we can make the greatest impact. We know because we have the conservation victories to prove it! That is why we created The Tide, a global community of action-takers from all races, genders, and walks of life, and we have room for more. You can be part of Paul’s 53rd journey around the sun, and you can help us turn the tide.  So what are you waiting for?  Join us in building a healthier world for all.
 
*visit only.one/giveaway-rules for eligibility.

node.text: I want to invite you all to join me tomorrow on @PaulNicklen’s birthday for a little fireside chat with @donnalapietra and Bill Kurtis through the link in my bio. My friend @susanbnoyes and Make It Better Media group are matching all donations made through the event, up to $25,000, for @SeaLegacy. We’ll talk about protecting our planet’s sacred resources and tackling the most urgent environmental issues through the lens of an artist. The most impactful solutions can arise from the confluence of art and science. Even a single photograph has the power to rekindle our intrinsic connection to the ocean and inspire us to take action. I hope to see you tomorrow at 3:15 pm EDT to delve more into what it means to be a force of change through photography and filmmaking. And don’t forget to wish Paul a happy birthday! @betterchicago @marinmagazine

node.text: This inquisitive little manatee popped up by the SeaLegacy 1 to greet our crew. I could see the scars from its encounters with boats and propellers along its tail and sides. It’s heartbreaking and infuriating to see such a trusting animal marred by the negligence of people. Across the state of Florida, manatees are facing a crisis. Careless dumping, the overuse of fertilizers, and rising global temperatures have created the perfect conditions for toxic algae blooms. Seagrass beds are dying off, and a spike in boat traffic has devastated delicate coastal ecosystems. As a result, manatees cannot feed and have been poisoned by the now lethal waters. Boat strikes are also on the rise, further endangering their lives. Click the link in my bio to learn how you can help protect these lovable animals with @AdoptAManatee. And please, please watch out for manatees while boating. @manateelagoon

node.text: A single dhow rests on the horizon as if suspended on the edge of the world along the shores of West Africa. Its silhouette grew smaller as we passed until the little patchwork sail finally slipped out of sight. Ever since I was little, I’ve dreamt of trading a life on land for mast and sails; to voyage out where sea meets sky and learn to navigate the most humbling forces of nature. The world’s earliest seafarers likely set out to provide for their families, extracting a living from the ocean from as far back as tens of thousands of years ago. But I wonder if they too felt the pull of the tides and that irresistible sense of adventure that sailing the seas instills. I made this fine art image, titled “Alone”, to capture that intrinsic connection so many of us seem to share with our ocean. To inquire about pricing on this print, or view more of my fine art portfolio, click the link in my bio. #fineart #fineartphotography #oceanphotography

node.text: #FineArtPrint “I See You” / @PaulNicklen and I met this little mountain gorilla on a hike in Rwanda’s misty mountain forests. He peered into my lens and I felt myself returning the smile in his eyes. It was a moment of trust and vulnerability - a rare glimpse into the mind of a wild animal so closely related to people. Spending time in the company of gorillas always reminds me that the barriers that separate us from other animals are not as concrete as we think they are. A phylogenetic tree may have many branches, but we all stem from the same roots. I made this image as a reminder that the future of young gorillas like this depends on how we choose to care for the planet we share with them. Click the link in my bio to read more about my fine art and inquire about pricing.
